introduction.p: As with most topics, we could spend a whole semester on inequalities. I normally concentrate on the relationship between the arithmetic, geometric and harmonic means, the Cauchy-Bunyakovsky-Schwarz inequality, and Young's inequality in a single class

section.title: Means
section.p: There are many means on a finite number of nonnegative real numbers. Here we focus on a few of the most common. The arithmetic mean of n numbers, or what we often call their average, is their sum divided by n. The geometric mean is computed by taking n^{th} root of their product. We establish the relationship between these two means in the following theorem.

proof.p: A proof by induction. We leave the proof for n=2 as an exercise. Then we assume that for some n \geq 2, the inequality is true and then assume we have n+1 numbers.

section.title: The CBS Inequality
section.p: The Cauchy-Bunyakovsky-Schwarz, or CBS, inequality has both discrete and continuous versions. The real discrete version follows.

statement.p: If x and y are vectors in \mathbb{R}^n, then \left(\sum _{i=1}^n x_i y_i\right){}^2\leq \left(\sum _{i=1}^n x_i^2\right)\left( \sum _{i=1}^n y_i^2\right) with equality if and only if the two vectors are scalar multiples of one another.

proof.p: There are many proofs of this inequality. Here is a brief one from THE BOOK. We observe that the inequality can be express more compactly using norm and inner product notation as (x, y)^2 \leq \left\Vert x \right\Vert^2 \left\Vert y \right\Vert^2 .
If x and y are linearly dependent, we get equality since the discriminant would equal zero.

section.title: Young's Inequality
section.p: Given positive numbers and whose reciprocals add up to one, the product of two positive real numbers and is less than or equal to a weighted sum of p^{th} and q^{th} powers of a and b.

statement.p: If a and b are nonnegative real numbers and p and q are positive real numbers such that \frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1, then a\cdot b \leq \frac{a^{p}}{p} + \frac{b^{q}}{q}.

proof.p: The proof follows from the following more general inequality, where f(x)=x^{p-1}.

statement.p: If f is a strictly increasing function on the positive real numbers, f(0)=0, and a and b are positive real numbers, then a b \leq \int_0^a f(x) \, dx +\int_0^b f^{-1}(y) \, dy

proof.p: If b=f(a), then the rectangle [0,a]\times[0,b] is divided into two regions, the region below the curve y=f(x), and the region to the left of x = f^{-1}(y). The sum of the two integrals is exactly equal to the area, a\cdot b. If f(a) \gt b, the region whose area \int_0^b f^{-1}(y) \, dy computes is contained within the rectangle, but the region whose area \int_0^a f(x) \, dx computes spills outside the rectangle, making the inequality a strict one. This case is illustrated by . In the other case, where f(a) \lt b, the excess area that makes the inequality a strict one is accounted for by \int_0^b f^{-1}(y) \, dy.

section.p: This interactive SageMath expression illustrates the proof above for the case where f(x)=x^{p-1}, p \gt 1.

sage.input: @interact() def young(a=(2,(1/4,3)),b=(3/2,(1/4,3)),p=(7/4,(1/8,5,1/8))): pl=plot(x^(p-1),(x,0,a),fill='min', fillcolor='red',ticks=[[],[]]) pl+=plot(x^(p-1),(x,0,b^(1/(p-1))),fill='max', fillcolor='blue') pl+=text('a='+str(n(a,3)),[a,-0.1]) pl+=text('b='+str(n(b,3)),[-0.1, b]) pl+=text('separating curve is \n$y=x^{p-1}$',[1.3*a,0.5*b]) show(pl,aspect_ratio=1)
